Knowledge Point: An imperative form in Fwe is formed with a suffix -e, but without the subject marker, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99102804}--\ref{bkm:Ref99102805}). The imperative form ending in -a, as commonly found in Bantu languages, does not exist in Fwe.
Content 1: \gsrc yêndè | \gll é̲nd-e | \gls go-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘Go!’
Content 2: \gsrc zwé hànò | \gll zw-é̲ hano | \gls come_out-PFV.SBJV DEM.II16 | \glt ‘Get out of here!’

Knowledge Point: The suffix -e is also used in the perfective subjunctive, which is only distinguished from the imperative form by the presence of the subject marker. The imperative and the perfective subjunctive also take the same melodic tones. When used without an object marker, the imperative takes melodic tone 1, combined with melodic tone 4, the deletion of underlying high tones, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref71903613}--\ref{bkm:Ref74908194}). (See \sectref{bkm:Ref71539267} for an overview of melodic tones.) With an object marker, the imperative combines melodic tone 4 with melodic tone 3 instead of melodic tone 1, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref71903625}--\ref{bkm:Ref74908216}).
Content 1: \gsrc hùwé ꜝcáhà | \gll huw-é̲ cáha | \gls shout-PFV.SBJV very | \glt ‘Shout loudly.’
Content 2: \gsrc fùrùmìké kàsúbà kò | \gll fuHrumik-é̲ ka-súba ko | \gls turn_upside_down-PFV.SBJV NP12-dish DEM.III12 | \glt ‘Turn that dish upside down.’

Knowledge Point: The imperative is used to express a command or order. An order expressed with the imperative is considered less polite and more direct than an order expressed with the subjunctive. The imperative can only be used for orders directed at a singular addressee, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref98771149}--\ref{bkm:Ref98771152}). Orders directed at plural addressees are expressed by subjunctives (see Sections \ref{bkm:Ref492309168}-\ref{bkm:Ref489363941}).
Content 1: \gsrc íwè tóndè kúnò | \gll iwé tó̲nd-e kunó | \gls PERS2SG watch-PFV.SBJV DEM.II17 | \glt ‘You! Look here!’

Knowledge Point: The perfective subjunctive form is formed with the suffix -e on the verb, and, unlike the imperative, takes a subject marker. Other than the presence of the subject marker, the perfective subjunctive is identical to the imperative, and also takes the same melodic tones: melodic tone 1 and 4 when the verb lacks an object marker, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref74908272}--\ref{bkm:Ref74908273}), or 3 and 4 when the verb includes an object marker, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref74908306}--\ref{bkm:Ref74908307}).
Content 1: \gsrc òtùmbùsé mùrìrò | \gll o-tuHmbus-é̲ mu-riro | \gls SM2SG-light-PFV.SBJV NP3-fire | \glt ‘You should light a fire.’
Content 2: \gsrc mùbíːkè òtúꜝcényà | \gll mu-bí̲ːk-e o-tú-cenyá | \gls SM2PL-put-PFV.SBJV AUG-NP13-small | \glt ‘You should put a little bit.’
Content 3: \gsrc tùmùbóózèrè ècìntú ꜝcákwè | \gll tu-mu-boó̲z-er-e e-ci-ntú cí-akwé | \gls SM1PL-OM1SG-return-APPL-SBJV AUG-NP7-thing PP7-POSS3SG | \glt ‘We should bring his thing back to him.’
Content 4: \gsrc tùzìbbátúrè èzí zìkûnì | \gll tu-ziH-bbaHt-ú̲r-e e-zí zi-kúni | \gls SM\-1PL-OM8-separate-SEP.TR-PFV.SBJV AUG-DEM.I8 NP8-tree | \glt ‘Can we separate these trees?’

Knowledge Point: The perfective subjunctive describes a one-time event, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99102952}), and contrasts with the imperfective subjunctive, which describes habitual or ongoing events, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99102971}) (see also \sectref{bkm:Ref489884199}).
Content 1: \gsrc òndìtúsè | \gll o-ndi-tus-é̲ | \gls SM2SG-OM1SG-help-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘You should help me (one time only).’
Content 2: \gsrc wákùndìtùsà | \gll o-áku-ndi-tus-a | \gls SM2SG-SBJV.IPFV-OM1SG-help-FV | \glt ‘You should help me regularly/be helping me.’

Knowledge Point: The perfective subjunctive has various functions. It can express a plan or intention, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref489953824}), where the speaker discusses what he plans to do to escape a fire.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The perfective subjunctive can be used to express volition or desire, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref449440622}--\ref{bkm:Ref449440623}).
Content 1: \gsrc nêyè àyéndè nêyè | \gll né=ye a-é̲nd-e né=ye | \gls COM=PERS3SG SM1-go-PFV.SBJV COM=PERS3SG | \glt ‘She too wanted to go with her.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndìpátámè | \gll ndi-patam-é̲ | \gls SM1SG-lie_on_stomach-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘I want to lie down a bit.’

Knowledge Point: When combined with the adverb nanga, the perfective subjunctive expresses uncertainty, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103032}--\ref{bkm:Ref99103033}). Note that the adverb nanga with the imperfective subjunctive does not express uncertainty, but immediate future (see \sectref{bkm:Ref489884199}).
Content 1: \gsrc nàngà bàkéːzyè bàtùpángé cìmwî | \gll nanga ba-ké̲ːzy-e ba-tuH-pang-é̲ ci-mwí | \gls even SM2-come-PFV.SBJV SM2-OM1PL-do-PFV.SBJV PP7-other | \glt ‘He might come and do something else to us.’

Knowledge Point: With a first person subject, the perfective subjunctive may express a hortative, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103056}--\ref{bkm:Ref99103057}).
Content 1: \gsrc tùràpérè | \gll tu-raper-é̲ | \gls SM1PL-pray-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘Let’s pray.’
Content 2: \gsrc kàntí ndìkùtòmbwérìsè | \gll kantí ndi-ku-tombwé̲r-is-e | \gls well SM1SG-OM2SG-weed-CAUS-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘Then let me help you weed.’

Knowledge Point: With a second person subject, the subjunctive may express a command, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103078}--\ref{bkm:Ref99103080}).
Content 1: \gsrc òkêːzyè òndìtúsè | \gll o-ké̲ːzy-e o-ndi-tus-é̲ | \gls SM2SG-come-PFV.SBJV SM2SG-OM1SG-help-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘Come and help me.’
Content 2: \gsrc mùtòntórè mùyéndè mùkàráːrè | \gll mu-toHntor-é̲ mu-é̲nd-e mu-ka-raːHr-é̲ | \gls SM2PL-be_quiet-PFV.SBJV SM2PL-go-PFV.SBJV SM2PL-DIST-sleep-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘Be quiet and go to sleep.’

Knowledge Point: A command expressed with the subjunctive form is usually interpreted as more polite than a command expressed with the imperative form (see \sectref{bkm:Ref489881434}). To express even more politeness, the prefix ngá- ‘can’ can be added, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103146}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Subjunctives are also used in subordinate clauses, where they can carry the same functions as subjunctives in main clauses, or can be used to express the desired or intended consequence of the event expressed in the main clause, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103166}--\ref{bkm:Ref99103168}).
Content 1: \gsrc bàmùbérékérà òkùtéyè \textbf{àfúmè} | \gll ba-mu-berek-er-á̲ okuteye a-fum-é̲ | \gls SM2-OM1-work-FV that SM1-become_rich-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘They work for him, \textbf{so} \textbf{that} \textbf{he} \textbf{becomes} \textbf{rich}.’

Knowledge Point: The perfective subjunctive can combine with the remoteness prefix na-; in subordinate clauses, this indicates a remote future, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref74908458}--\ref{bkm:Ref74908459}). In main clauses, the perfective subjunctive with na- expresses the same functions as the perfective subjunctive without na-, only set in the remote future, such as a command to be followed up tomorrow, not today. This use is illustrated in (\ref{bkm:Ref74908501}--\ref{bkm:Ref74908502}). Remoteness is usually considered as at least one day removed from the day of speaking, as it is throughout the tense/aspect system of Fwe (see, for instance, the remote past perfective, \sectref{bkm:Ref489260766}).
Content 1: \gsrc mbùtí náyìwánè èyí shérêŋì | \gll N-bu-tí na-á̲-iH-wan-é̲ e-í ∅-sheréŋi | \gls COP-NP14-how REM-SM1-OM9-find-PFV.SBJV AUG-DEM.I9 NP9-money | \glt ‘How will he get this money?’
Content 3: \gsrc nóyêndè zyônà | \gll na-ó̲-é̲nd-e zyóna | \gls REM-SM2SG-go-PFV.SBJV tomorrow | \glt ‘Go tomorrow.’
Content 4: \gsrc nìbézyè bàkùbónè | \gll ni-bá̲-izy-e ba-ku-boHn-é̲ | \gls REM-SM2SG-come-PFV.SBJV SM2-OM2SG-see-PFV.SBJV | \glt ‘She has to come and take care of you.’

Knowledge Point: The remoteness prefix na- is used with the verb ta ‘say’ in the subjunctive, followed by a subjunctive main verb, to express an event that almost, but not quite, took place, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103237}--\ref{bkm:Ref99103238}).
Content 1: \gsrc nàté ndìmùcáîsè zywínà | \gll na-ta-é̲ ndi-mu-caí̲s-e zwiná | \gls REM-say-PFV.SBJV SM1SG-OM1-bump_into-PFV.SBJV DEM.IV1 | \glt ‘I almost bumped into her/him, that one.’

Knowledge Point: An imperfective subjunctive is formed with the post-initial prefix áku-, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103273}). Verbs in the imperfective subjunctive maintain their underlying tones, and aside from the high tone associated with the prefix áku- itself, no melodic high tones are added.
Content 1: \gsrc ènwé ꜝbáꜝnángù mwákùkàrà | \gll enwé bá-na-angú mu-áku-kar-a | \gls PERS2PL NP2-child-POSS1SG SM2PL-SBJV.IPFV-stay-FV | \glt ‘You, my children, must stay here.’

Knowledge Point: The second syllable ku of the prefix áku- is derived from the infinitive prefix ku-. Two of the characteristics of the imperfective subjunctive point to its origin in an infinitive: the fact that the syllable ku may change to ka when used with the distal marker (see (\ref{bkm:Ref490842863})), and the lack of melodic tones, which is typical of infinitives and rarely seen in inflected verbs (see also \sectref{bkm:Ref71540393}).
Content 1: \gsrc nàngà ndákàyà | \gll nanga ndi-áka-y-a | \gls even SM1SG-SBJV.IPFV.DIST-go-FV | \glt ‘I am about to leave.’

Knowledge Point: Habitual is a subtype of imperfective aspect, and the imperfective subjunctive is therefore often used with a habitual meaning, combined with the habitual suffix -ang, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103335}) (see also \sectref{bkm:Ref451268511}).
Content 1: \gsrc wákùmùtùsàngà | \gll o-áku-mu-tus-ang-a | \gls SM2SG-SBJV.IPFV-OM1-help-HAB-FV | \glt ‘You should help her/him regularly.’

Knowledge Point: Without the habitual suffix -ang, both a habitual and a progressive reading are possible, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103358}). The imperfective subjunctive does not combine with overt progressive markers, and in most cases, such as in (\ref{bkm:Ref99103360}), the habitual reading appears to be preferred.
Content 1: \gsrc wákùmùtùsà | \gll o-áku-mu-tus-a | \gls SM2SG-SBJV.IPFV-OM1-help-FV | \glt ‘You should be helping her/him.’ / ‘You should help her/him regularly.’
Content 2: \gsrc wákùmùtùsàngà | \gll o-áku-mu-tus-ang-a | \gls SM2SG-SBJV.IPFV-OM1-help-HAB-FV | \glt ‘You should help her/him regularly.’

Knowledge Point: More data are needed to study the range of meanings of the imperfective subjunctive, though it appears to be similar to that of the perfective subjunctive, e.g. a command, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref489953949}), or a hortative, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref489953950}).
Content 1: \gsrc mwákùrítèèzà | \gll mu-áku-rí-teez-a | \gls SM2-SBJV.IPFV-REFL-listen-FV | \glt ‘You have to listen to each other.’
Content 2: \gsrc ndákùmènèkàngà | \gll ndi-áku-menek-ang-a | \gls SM1SG-SBJV.IPFV-wake_early-HAB-FV | \glt ‘I should regularly wake up early.’

Knowledge Point: Like the perfective subjunctive, the imperfective subjunctive may combine with the adverb nanga ‘even’, not to express uncertainty, as is the case for the perfective subjunctive, but to express immediate future, as in (\ref{bkm:Ref490842863}--\ref{bkm:Ref99103420}).
Content 1: \gsrc nàngà ndákàyà | \gll nanga ndi-áka-y-a | \gls even SM1SG-SBJV.IPFV.DIST-go-FV | \glt ‘I am about to leave.’
Content 2: \gsrc nàngà bákùhùrà ndìkàréː ꜝbákànànúkà | \gll nanga ba-áku-hur-a ndi-ka-réː bá̲-ka-nanuk-á̲ | \gls even SM2-SBJV.IPFV-arrive-FV COP-ADV-long SM2.REL-DIST-leave-FV | \glt ‘S/he is about to arrive, s/he left a long time ago.’
